message_1:
A student is planning to go on a hiking trip and can carry a maximum weight of 15 kg in their backpack. They have a set of 6 items to choose from, each with its own weight and value. The details are:

Item 1: weight 2 kg, value $10
Item 2: weight 3 kg, value $15
Item 3: weight 5 kg, value $20
Item 4: weight 7 kg, value $25
Item 5: weight 9 kg, value $30
Item 6: weight 11 kg, value $35

What is the maximum value of items the student can carry in their backpack? Assume that only whole items can be taken and individual items cannot be divided.
message_2:
To maximize the value of items the student can carry in their backpack, we can use a greedy algorithm. We will sort the items by their value-to-weight ratio and then select the items with the highest ratio until the backpack is full or no more items can be added.

Value-to-weight ratios:
Item 1: 10/2 = 5
Item 2: 15/3 = 5
Item 3: 20/5 = 4
Item 4: 25/7 ≈ 3.57
Item 5: 30/9 ≈ 3.33
Item 6: 35/11 ≈ 3.18

Sorted by value-to-weight ratio:
1. Item 1 (5)
2. Item 2 (5)
3. Item 3 (4)
4. Item 4 (3.57)
5. Item 5 (3.33)
6. Item 6 (3.18)

Now, we will select items in this order until the backpack is full or no more items can be added:

1. Add Item 1: weight = 2 kg, value = $10, remaining capacity = 15 - 2 = 13 kg
2. Add Item 2: weight = 3 kg, value = $15, remaining capacity = 13 - 3 = 10 kg
3. Add Item 3: weight = 5 kg, value = $20, remaining capacity = 10 - 5 = 5 kg

At this point, we cannot add any more items without exceeding the backpack's weight limit. The maximum value of items the student can carry in their backpack is $10 + $15 + $20 = $45.
